what: Replace text in files using sed run in bash. — ngr_sed_replace_in_files
title: Replace text in files using sed run in bash. — ngr_sed_replace_in_files
text: function superseded ngr_str_replace_in_files(). Please use ngr_str_replace_in_files() future implementations since safer allows user review replacements performing . function performs bulk find--replace operation given set files. replaces occurrences text_current text_replace using sed, handling word boundaries trailing punctuation.

title: Replace text in files using sed run in bash. — ngr_sed_replace_in_files
Replace text in files using sed run in bash. — ngr_sed_replace_in_files
text: text_current character string representing text replaced. text_replace character string representing replacement text. files character vector file paths replacement applied.

title: Replace text in files using sed run in bash. — ngr_sed_replace_in_files
text: Invisibly returns result processx::run command.

title: Replace text in files using sed run in bash. — ngr_sed_replace_in_files
text: Running example result modifications specified files. Ensure working test files backups running function.

title: Replace text in files using sed run in bash. — ngr_sed_replace_in_files
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Example usage: # Define the strings to replace and their replacements keys_matched <- data.frame(   key_missing = c("exampleOldText", "anotherOldValue"),   key_missing_guess_match = c("exampleNewText", "anotherNewValue"),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Example files (replace these paths with your own test files) file_list <- c("test_file1.txt", "test_file2.txt")  # Run the replacements (note: this will modify the specified files!) purrr::map2(   .x = keys_matched$key_missing,   .y = keys_matched$key_missing_guess_match,   ~ ngr_sed_replace_in_files(text_current = .x, text_replace = .y, files = file_list) ) } # }

Filter Rows Based on String Detection in a Column Detected with a partial String Match — ngr_str_df_detect_filter
text: x data.frame input data frame filter. col_filter character single string representing pattern match column names. str_filter character single string match within values filtered column.

title: Filter Rows Based on String Detection in a Column Detected with a partial String Match — ngr_str_df_detect_filter
text: filtered data frame matching rows found; otherwise, original data frame returned.

what: Detect the Presence of a Specific File in a Directory — ngr_str_dir_from_file

title: Detect the Presence of a Specific File in a Directory — ngr_str_dir_from_file
Detect the Presence of a Specific File in a Directory — ngr_str_dir_from_file
text: path_dir character single string representing directory path search. file_name character string specifying name file detect. recurse logical Whether search recursively subdirectories. Default FALSE. ... Additional arguments passed fs::dir_ls().

title: Detect the Presence of a Specific File in a Directory — ngr_str_dir_from_file
text: character directory path file found; otherwise, warning issued.

what: Extract Directory Name from File or Directory Path Based on Levels — ngr_str_dir_from_path
title: Extract Directory Name from File or Directory Path Based on Levels — ngr_str_dir_from_path
text: function retrieves directory name specified level(s) given file path. wraps fs::path_dir() navigate directory levels basename() extract final directory name. Particularly useful retrieving repo name can converted url html link ngr_str_link_repo().

title: Extract Directory Name from File or Directory Path Based on Levels — ngr_str_dir_from_path
Extract Directory Name from File or Directory Path Based on Levels — ngr_str_dir_from_path
text: path character single string. file path. levels integer single integer. number levels traverse file path extract directory name. Default 1.

title: Extract Directory Name from File or Directory Path Based on Levels — ngr_str_dir_from_path
text: character single string representing directory name specified level.

title: Extract Directory Name from File or Directory Path Based on Levels — ngr_str_dir_from_path

what: Create an HTML Link to Repository Resources or GitHub Pages — ngr_str_link_repo
title: Create an HTML Link to Repository Resources or GitHub Pages — ngr_str_link_repo
text: function generates HTML <> tag linking specified repository resource GitHub Pages site hosted repository. particularly useful embedding links HTML documents.

title: Create an HTML Link to Repository Resources or GitHub Pages — ngr_str_link_repo
Create an HTML Link to Repository Resources or GitHub Pages — ngr_str_link_repo
text: repo_source character single string representing repository name linked. url character single string specifying base URL repository host. Default New Graph gitpages https://www.newgraphenvironment.com". https://github.com/NewGraphEnvironment gets repository . anchor_text character single string specifying text displayed link. Defaults "url_link". target character single string indicating target attribute HTML link. Default "_blank". Options include: "_blank": Opens link new tab window. "_self": Opens link tab window. "_parent": Opens link parent frame, applicable. "_top": Opens link full body window, ignoring frames.

title: Create an HTML Link to Repository Resources or GitHub Pages — ngr_str_link_repo
text: character single string containing HTML <> tag.

title: Create an HTML Link to Repository Resources or GitHub Pages — ngr_str_link_repo
text: function can create links either: Repository resources: Links directly repository platforms like GitHub. GitHub Pages: Links websites documentation served repository, using base URL hosted site. provided url start http:// https://, warning issued indicate potential issues generated links.

title: Create an HTML Link to Repository Resources or GitHub Pages — ngr_str_link_repo
code: # Example 1: Link to the repository with default anchor text ngr_str_link_repo("ngr", url = "https://github.com/NewGraphEnvironment") #> [1] "url_link" # Example 2: Link to GitHub Pages with anchor text set to the repository name ngr_str_link_repo("ngr", url = "https://www.newgraphenvironment.com", anchor_text = "ngr") #> [1] "ngr"

what: Rename Files and Directories Containing Specific Text — ngr_str_replace_filenames
title: Rename Files and Directories Containing Specific Text — ngr_str_replace_filenames
text: function renames files directories replacing occurrences specified text new text. allows exclusions inclusions using glob patterns provides option confirm changes applying .

title: Rename Files and Directories Containing Specific Text — ngr_str_replace_filenames
code: ngr_str_replace_filenames(   path = ".",   text_current,   text_replace,   glob_exclude = ".git",   glob_include = NULL,   ask = TRUE )

title: Rename Files and Directories Containing Specific Text — ngr_str_replace_filenames
text: path character vector one paths. root directory start searching files directories. text_current character string representing text replaced filenames. text_replace character string representing new text replace current text filenames. glob_exclude character glob pattern exclude specific paths renaming. Default ".git". glob_include character NULL glob pattern include specific files directories. Default NULL. ask logical Whether prompt user confirmation renaming. Default TRUE.

title: Rename Files and Directories Containing Specific Text — ngr_str_replace_filenames
text: NULL invisibly completing renaming operation.

title: Rename Files and Directories Containing Specific Text — ngr_str_replace_filenames
text: function uses stringr::str_detect() find filenames containing specified text_current excludes text_replace already present. renames files directories accordingly using fs::file_move().

what: Perform Bulk Find-and-Replace on Multiple Files Using stringr — ngr_str_replace_in_files
title: Perform Bulk Find-and-Replace on Multiple Files Using stringr — ngr_str_replace_in_files
text: function explicitly reads content files, performs find--replace operations using stringr, writes updated content back files. handles word boundaries, trailing punctuation, allows specific symbols like @ precede text replaced.

title: Perform Bulk Find-and-Replace on Multiple Files Using stringr — ngr_str_replace_in_files
Perform Bulk Find-and-Replace on Multiple Files Using stringr — ngr_str_replace_in_files
text: text_current character string representing text replaced filenames. text_replace character string representing new text replace current text filenames. ask logical Whether prompt user confirmation renaming. Default TRUE.

title: Perform Bulk Find-and-Replace on Multiple Files Using stringr — ngr_str_replace_in_files
text: logical Invisibly returns logical vector indicating success file.

what: Remove Columns with All NA Values — ngr_tidy_cols_rm_na
title: Remove Columns with All NA Values — ngr_tidy_cols_rm_na
text: ngr_tidy_cols_rm_na removes columns data.frame every value NA. can particularly helper attempting join data.frames due type conflicts occur due columns NA values.

title: Remove Columns with All NA Values — ngr_tidy_cols_rm_na
Remove Columns with All NA Values — ngr_tidy_cols_rm_na
text: df data.frame. input data frame cleaned.

title: Remove Columns with All NA Values — ngr_tidy_cols_rm_na
text: data.frame columns containing NA values removed.

title: Remove Columns with All NA Values — ngr_tidy_cols_rm_na
code: # Example data frame df <- data.frame(   A = c(NA, NA, NA),   B = c(1, 2, NA),   C = c(NA, NA, NA),   D = c("x", "y", NA) )  # Apply the function tidy_df <- ngr_tidy_cols_rm_na(df)  # Result print(tidy_df) #>    B    D #> 1  1    x #> 2  2    y #> 3 NA <NA>

what: Compare Column Type Consistency Across Nested Dataframes — ngr_tidy_cols_type_compare
title: Compare Column Type Consistency Across Nested Dataframes — ngr_tidy_cols_type_compare
text: function checks column type consistency across multiple dataframes nested list.

title: Compare Column Type Consistency Across Nested Dataframes — ngr_tidy_cols_type_compare
Compare Column Type Consistency Across Nested Dataframes — ngr_tidy_cols_type_compare
text: nested_list_df list named list dataframes, dataframe expected consistent column names.

title: Compare Column Type Consistency Across Nested Dataframes — ngr_tidy_cols_type_compare
text: data.frame following columns: col_name: name column. types: comma-separated string unique types found column across datasets. consistent: logical value indicating whether column types consistent across datasets.

title: Compare Column Type Consistency Across Nested Dataframes — ngr_tidy_cols_type_compare
text: function inspects class column across list dataframes. aggregates unique types column determines column types consistent across datasets list.

title: Compare Column Type Consistency Across Nested Dataframes — ngr_tidy_cols_type_compare
code: nested_list_df <- list(   df1 = data.frame(a = 1:3, b = c("x", "y", "z"), c = as.Date("2023-01-01") + 0:2, stringsAsFactors = FALSE),   df2 = data.frame(a = c(1.1, 2.2, 3.3), b = c("x", "y", "z"), c = c(TRUE, FALSE, TRUE), stringsAsFactors = FALSE),   df3 = data.frame(a = c("one", "two", "three"), b = c("x", "y", "z"), c = as.Date("2023-01-01") + 0:2, stringsAsFactors = FALSE) ) ngr_tidy_cols_type_compare(nested_list_df) #>   col_name                       types consistent #> 1        a integer, numeric, character      FALSE #> 2        b                   character       TRUE #> 3        c               Date, logical      FALSE
